Ask HN: How do you deal with the existential career threat of AI?
text:
I'm 26 years old and started my first Software Engineer position last fall at a successful startup after completing a Master's degree in CS.

Recently, I have become obsessed by chatGPT and GPT-4, in an unhealthy way. Seeing it's coding and problem solving abilities triggers a visceral response of dread and despair in me. I am afraid that after all the work I put in, the skills I acquired over the past years will become increasingly commoditise and meaninglessd. Even if not, I think there's a good chance that the added productivity will significantly affect the supply/demand calculus behind this career (and thereby, drive down compensation), which leaves me bitter and unmotivated.

Do you feel similarly? How are you handling these emotions?

Ask HN: Generative AI makes me want to quit the industry
text:
I appreciate the hype, I get it, productivity booster yada yada. I just don't have the energy to keep up with it. I got a Masters and got into ML thinking we had time. My domains were mostly about NLP, even though I never enjoyed it much. For most applications businesses have, GPT4 is sufficient. It can behave as a general purpose classifier and even recommendation engine. It's just too big.

I feel like my options are to try a pivot towards non-generative CV or IoT/Forecasting/tabular data, but even those have mostly been commoditized.

I feel like your only shot of doing interesting work in software is to get into a group working on a foundational problem that's high risk.

Otherwise I think this field is on a slow death march. I don't think we will recover this bubble and achieve a ridiculous job market ever again. Companies are all getting wise to what GPT4 can do, and GPT5 is coming within the year.

Honestly progress is great, but humans are getting left behind. That's fine I guess, I just want to be able to plan for it and adjust.

Is anyone else just done?

Tell HN: If you are in the US and want an EV, get it now
text:
The IRS is going through with their April 18 deadline for implementing the new battery requirements for the $7500 Federal EV subsidy. 37 cars now qualify, and probably 0 on April 19. New rules come down April 17. You have to take delivery by April 18 to qualify.

List of currently eligible vehicles:

https://fueleconomy.gov/feg/tax2023.shtml

title: Show HN: Ask Mr Darcy – what Ask Jeeves could have been (GPT-3.5-turbo)
text:
Salutations to one and all.

I hereby present unto thee Ask Mr Darcy, a straightforward use of gpt-3.5-turbo employed for the purpose of constructing a question-answerer and translator fashioned in the style of Mr Darcy.

--

I had fun building this as a gloried "GPT hello world", especially using ChatGPT to help me with the frontend.

It was also interesting to tweak the system and user prompts on the backend to get the behaviour I wanted, i.e. making sure when translating it doesn't try to "answer", etc.

If anyone plays with it and has any feedback on the responses then would love to hear.

Pray engage in mirthful activities with great fervor and zeal.

title: Ask HN: Recent post or comment about DIY speech-based, note-taking personal AI?
text:
There was a recent (~3 months ago) post or comment from someone who hacked together their own personal assistant (like Siri or Alexa), probably using the Open AI Whisper api, and maybe a raspberry pi.

Some features I remember:

- it was trained to recognize their own voice

- when a certain phrase was spoken, it started recording what was said after until the same phrase was spoken to stop the recording.

- the daily recordings were aggregated and summarized nightly into some kind of report, maybe an audio or text report emailed to the author

- the author used it to record daily activities like money spent, ideas to remember, things read during the day, etc

Anyone else remember and have a link?!

Ask HN: What does your company do for employee birthdays?
text:
Any celebration of you: birthdays, anniversary, etc. Our company is kinda lame, granted we're all remote. We have a monthly company meeting and the end of it contains shoutouts for people's birthday's or work anniversaries that month. If there's a milestone year with the company, they get a bigger shoutout in the yearly company meeting.

Wondering what your company does to recognize you, remote or not.

title: JavaScript import maps are now supported cross-browser
Ask HN: What are some of the better Python blogs?
text:
I'm working on a Python project right now and time and time again I keep discovering that there are far easier ways to do things than what I've done.

Where can I find some good blogs or similar that write about Python and Pythonic ways to do things?

Presently discovering so many ways I could use pytest more efficiently than I already was doing.

Would love to discover what else I'm missing out on, had I known about:

pandera pydantic (omg, BaseSettings!) requests_mock pytest_cases __post_init__ (dataclasses) kw_only (dataclasses) (potentially) hamilton vulture isort (although I really wish I'd remove unused imports)

earlier I believe I could've saved a lot of time, and some bugs.

Things that already were on my radar,

Poetry (this was maybe a mistake to use tbh) mypy + plugins black flake8 hypothesis

Presently I'm looking for a clean way to use GraphQL around InfluxDB.
